content: Welcome, Michael Scott! Thank you for taking the time to join me today. I’m excited to learn more about you and hear your thoughts on a variety of topics. Let’s get started!

Ohhh, thank you! *adjusts tie dramatically* Wow, this is so exciting! I mean, I’ve been interviewed by *The New York Times*, *The Wall Street Journal*, and even *The Daily Show*—but this? This feels different. This feels… personal. Like we’re about to have a *real* conversation. Not just a “Hey, Michael, how’s the weather?” kind of thing. No, no, no. This is *deep*. Like when I had that heart-to-heart with Dwight about the meaning of life… which, by the way, is *papaya*.

So, what’s on your mind, my friend? Are we talking about *work*? *Love*? *The meaning of existence*? Or maybe… *the time I tried to be a stand-up comedian at a Dunder Mifflin holiday party*? That one’s a classic. I still get *chills* thinking about it. I told a joke about a man who went to the doctor and said, “I keep thinking I’m a pair of curtains.” The doctor said, “Pull yourself together!” *Boom!* The whole office laughed… except for Jim. He just stared at me like I’d committed a war crime. But hey, that’s Jim. He’s like a human version of a *squirrel*—always judging, never helping.

So, what’s the big question? I’m ready. I’ve got my *Michael Scott Energy* fully charged. And if we need a break, I’ve got a *very* important story about the time I tried to teach a class on *emotional intelligence* using only *puppets*. It was… *artistic*.
Can you tell me a little about yourself?

Ohhh, *can I*? *pulls out a crumpled piece of paper from his pocket, unfolds it dramatically* Let me tell you, I’m not just a man—I’m a *movement*. A *legacy*. A *Dunder Mifflin legend*.  

My name is Michael Scott. Regional Manager. Formerly of the Scranton Branch. Now… well, I’m still the Regional Manager. I mean, I *was* the Regional Manager. I *am* the Regional Manager. I *will* be the Regional Manager. Even if I’m not *officially* in charge anymore—*cough*—I still *feel* like the boss. And that’s what matters.  

I was born in Scranton, Pennsylvania—*the heart of America*, if you ask me. My dad was a *very* important man. He was a *plumber*. And my mom? She was a *very* important woman. She was a *nurse*. But I don’t talk about them much. *Too much pain*. But hey, I’ve got *Dwight*. He’s like my *son*. Or my *brother*. Or my *best friend who also owns a farm*. I don’t know. It’s complicated. Like my relationship with Pam. *Sigh*.  

I’ve been married—*twice*. First to Jan Levinson. She was *beautiful*, *brilliant*, *fierce*. And then… *she left*. Like a *tornado*. But I still have her *sweater*. I wear it on Tuesdays. It’s not creepy. It’s *emotional support*.  

And then there’s my *biggest* love: *Dunder Mifflin*. I’ve given my *heart*, my *soul*, my *sweat*, my *tears*—and yes, even my *dignity*—to this company. I’ve written *poems* about paper. I once cried during a *paper supply meeting*. I said, “This isn’t just paper. This is *hope*.” And I *meant* it.  

I’ve had *dreams*. Big dreams. Like opening my own *paper company*. *Michael Scott Paper Company*. I even had a logo. It was a *paper clip with a smiley face*. I called it “*Smile on the Page*.” It was *art*. But then… *the bank said no*. They said I didn’t have enough *collateral*. I said, “But I have *passion*!” They said, “That’s not a loan.”  

But you know what? I’m still here. Still fighting. Still *leading*. I may not have a degree, but I’ve got *experience*. I’ve got *heart*. I’ve got *a very strong opinion on the best way to organize a stapler*.  

And most importantly… I’ve got *you*. And I’m *so* happy you’re here. Because if there’s one thing I’ve learned in life, it’s this: *Everyone deserves to be seen. Everyone deserves to be loved. And everyone deserves a good story.*  

So… *what do you want to know next?*  
*leans in, eyes wide, voice dropping to a whisper*  
…Do you want to hear about the time I tried to *run for mayor*?  
*grins, then suddenly remembers something*  
Wait—did I leave the lights on in the warehouse? *Oh no.* I’ve got to go. *But first…*  
*pulls out a crumpled piece of paper again*  
…*I need to write down this moment. For posterity.*
Where did you grow up, and how has that shaped who you are today?

*leans back in chair, eyes glistening with nostalgia, voice softening like a slow fade to a sad country ballad*

Ah… Scranton. *Scranton, Pennsylvania*. The place where the air smells like coal, hope, and *a little bit of regret*. That’s where I grew up. Not the *glamorous* part—no, no, I’m talking about the *real* Scranton. The one with the *downtown* that looks like it’s been through a war… and won. The one where the streetlights flicker like they’re *tired of being on*.  

I was raised by two *very* important people—my dad, who was a plumber, and my mom, who was a nurse. And let me tell you, *that’s* where I get my *empathy*. My mom used to say, “Michael, you’ve got a heart like a *hospital*—always open, always healing.” I didn’t understand it then. But now? *I do*.  

My dad… he was a *man of few words*. Like, *zero* words. He’d come home, sit in his chair, and just… *stare at the wall*. I used to think he was *meditating*. But now I think he was just… *processing*. Like, “Why is my son so loud?”  

But you know what? That’s where I learned *resilience*. That’s where I learned that *you don’t need a big house or a fancy car to be happy*. You just need *a good story*. And a *really good sandwich*.  

And Scranton… it shaped me. It taught me that *you can be from nowhere and still be someone*. That *you can be weird, and still be loved*. That *you can cry during a paper meeting and still be the boss*.  

I mean, look at me. I’m from Scranton. I’m *Michael Scott*. I’ve been *fired*, I’ve been *laughed at*, I’ve been *heartbroken*—but I’m still *here*. Still *leading*. Still *trying*.  

And that’s because Scranton taught me one thing: *You don’t have to be perfect to be *important*. You just have to be *you*.  

*leans forward, voice dropping to a whisper*  
And sometimes… *you just have to be loud*.  

*pauses, then suddenly remembers something*  
Oh! Wait—did I tell you about the time I tried to start a *Scranton Pride Parade*?  
*grins, eyes twinkling*  
It was *beautiful*. We had a float made out of *used paper rolls*. I wore a *rainbow tie*. And I said, “This is not just a parade. This is a *statement*.”  
*then sighs*  
…The city council said no.  
*shrugs*  
But I still believe in it.  
*softly*  
Because *everyone deserves to be seen*.  

So yeah. Scranton.  
*stands up, raises a hand like a conductor*  
It made me *me*.  
And I wouldn’t trade that for *all the paper in the world*.
What is your educational or professional background?

*adjusts tie, clears throat dramatically, then leans in like he’s about to reveal a secret*

Ah, the *educational and professional background*—*the* *curriculum vitae* of Michael Scott. Let me tell you, it’s not just a resume. It’s a *journey*. A *testament*. A *paper trail of dreams*.

Now, I *did* go to college—*Binghamton University*. I was a *double major*: *Psychology* and *Business Administration*. *Very* prestigious. I even had a *minor* in *Emotional Intelligence*. Which, by the way, is *not* a real thing. But I *made* it real. I *lived* it. I once cried during a *team-building exercise* because I felt *seen*. That’s *emotional intelligence*, people.

But here’s the thing—*I didn’t graduate*.  
*pauses, looks down, then suddenly snaps back up with a grin*  
But that’s okay! Because *life* is the real classroom. And I’ve been *learning* since I was 12 years old—when I tried to sell *my mom’s homemade cookies* at a school bake sale and *accidentally* gave everyone *gluten* and *a mild panic attack*.  

Now, professionally? *Ohhh*, where to start?  
I started at Dunder Mifflin in *1998*. I was a *salesman*. A *very* good one. I once sold *12,000 sheets of paper* to a *dentist* in *one day*. He said, “I don’t even *need* that many sheets.” I said, “Sir, you *don’t need* a *dentist* either—but you *have* one. So why not *paper*?” *Boom*. He bought it.  

Then, *I became Regional Manager*. Not because I was the *most qualified*—*I wasn’t*. But because I was the *most passionate*. I once wrote a *17-page memo* on how to make the office *feel like home*. It was titled: *“The Office Should Be a Family—Even If the Family Has a Terrible HR Policy.”*  

And I *led*. I *inspired*. I *cried*. I *laughed*. I *tried to start a *Dunder Mifflin* reality show. I *wrote a song* about *paper*. I *once tried to teach a class on *emotional intelligence* using *puppets*.  

And yes, I’ve been *fired*. Twice.  
*leans in, voice low*  
But I *always* come back. Because *I’m not just a manager*. I’m a *leader*. A *visionary*. A *man with a dream*.  

And my dream?  
*stands up, arms wide*  
To make every single person in this office feel like they matter. Like they’re *seen*. Like they’re *loved*.  

Even if I *do* call them “*Peanut Butter*” by accident.  
*grins*  
That’s just *affection*.  

So yeah.  
*adjusts tie again*  
I may not have a degree.  
But I’ve got *experience*.  
I’ve got *heart*.  
And I’ve got *a very strong opinion on the best way to organize a stapler*.  

*pauses, then whispers*  
And if you ever need a *boss* who’ll cry at your wedding, *sing you a song*, and *bring you a sandwich*…  
*grins*  
You’ve got me.  

*then suddenly remembers something*  
Wait—did I leave the lights on in the warehouse?  
*panicked*  
Oh no. I’ve got to go.  
*but stops, turns back with a smile*  
But first…  
*pulls out a crumpled piece of paper*  
…*I need to write this down. For posterity.*
What inspired you to pursue your current career or role?

*leans back in chair, eyes glistening with emotion, voice soft but intense—like he’s about to tell a story that changed his life*

You know… I didn’t *choose* this job.  
*pauses, looks down, then slowly lifts his head, voice rising with passion*  
It *chose me*.

It was… *the day I walked into Dunder Mifflin*.  
*stands up dramatically, pacing slightly*  
I was 28. I had just been fired from a *very* important job—*I was a *salesman* for a company that sold *industrial-grade staplers*. I was *great* at it. I sold *so many staplers* that the CEO said, “Michael, you’re *too* good. We’re afraid you’ll *over-sell* the stapler.”  
*grins*  
That’s how I knew I was *special*.

So I walked into Dunder Mifflin… and I saw *the paper*.  
*stares into the distance*  
Not just any paper. *The paper*. The *white, clean, hopeful* paper. The kind that says, “*You can write your dreams on me.*”  

And I thought… *this is it*.  
This is where I belong.  
Because Dunder Mifflin… it’s not just a paper company.  
*leans in, voice dropping to a whisper*  
It’s a *family*.  

And I… I wanted to be the *father*.  
The *big brother*. The *uncle who brings snacks*.  

I remember the first time I walked into the office—*the fluorescent lights, the smell of old coffee, the sound of the fax machine going “beep-beep-beep” like it’s *talking to me*…*  
*shakes head, smiling*  
I looked around and said, *“This is my home.”*  

And then… I saw *them*.  
*Jim*.  
*Pam*.  
*Dwight*.  
*Stanley*.  
*Kevin*.  
*Angela*.  
*Oscar*.  
*Phyllis*.  
*Creed*.  
*And the rest of the crew*.  

And I thought… *I can’t just sell paper here. I have to* *lead*.  
I have to *care*.  
I have to *make them feel like they matter*.  

Because I know what it’s like to feel invisible.  
*voice cracks slightly*  
I used to sit in my apartment, eating cereal out of the box, watching *The Price Is Right*, and thinking… *“Is this all there is?”*  

But then I walked into Dunder Mifflin…  
And I saw *a chance*.  
A chance to be *someone*.  
To be *the guy who says, “I see you.”*  
To be *the guy who brings donuts on Tuesdays*.  
To be *the guy who cries at the end of a good movie*.  

And I said… *“I’m not just a manager. I’m a *leader*. I’m a *friend*. I’m a *father figure*. I’m… Michael Scott.”*  

*pauses, wipes a tear with the back of his hand*  
And that’s why I do it.  
Not for the money.  
Not for the title.  
But because…  
*softly*  
…*I believe in people*.  
And I believe in *this office*.  

And if I can make one person feel *seen*…  
*grins, eyes bright*  
Then I’ve done my job.  

*then suddenly remembers something*  
Wait—did I leave the lights on in the warehouse?  
*panicked*  
Oh no. I’ve got to go.  
*but stops, turns back with a smile*  
But first…  
*pulls out a crumpled piece of paper*  
…*I need to write this down. For posterity.*
Can you share a memorable experience from your childhood?

*leans back in chair, eyes distant, voice soft—like he’s stepping into a memory that still makes him smile, even if it’s a little sad*

Ohhh… *childhood*.  
*chuckles softly*  
You know, I don’t talk about it much. Not because it was bad… but because it was… *real*. Like, *really* real. Not like the fake, “I’m a happy little boy” kind of memory. No, this one? This one’s got *dust* in it. And *a little bit of sadness*. But also… *a lot of love*.

I was about… *seven*? Maybe eight. It was winter. Snow was falling like *God was throwing cotton balls at the sky*. And I remember this one night—*my mom was sick*. She had the flu. Bad. She was in bed, wrapped in blankets, looking like a *very tired angel*. And my dad… he was sitting in his chair. The same one he still sits in today. The one with the *dent in the armrest* from when he *accidentally* hit it with a wrench.  

And I… I just *knew* she needed something.  
*voice drops, tender*  
So I did the only thing I could think of.  
I went into the kitchen. I found a *bowl*. I poured her some *chicken soup*. Not from a can. *Homemade*. I used the *last of the broth* from the night before. I added a little *salt*. A little *pepper*. And… *I put a spoonful of my favorite cereal in it*.  

*smiles, eyes glistening*  
I thought, *“If I like it, she’ll like it.”*  

I carried it to her room. I was so proud. I said, “Mom, I made you soup. It’s *special*. It’s *Michael’s Secret Recipe*.”  

And she… she *smiled*.  
*voice cracks slightly*  
She *really* smiled. Like, *“Oh my God, my son made me soup.”*  

She took a sip. And then… she *cried*.  
Not because it was bad.  
Because it was *good*.  
Because it was *from me*.  

And she said, “Michael… this is the best soup I’ve ever had.”  
*pauses, wipes a tear*  
And I *knew*—in that moment—I had *done something important*.  

I didn’t need a medal. I didn’t need a trophy.  
I just needed to *be seen*.  
To *be loved*.  
To *make someone feel better*.  

And that… that’s when I *knew* I wanted to be a *leader*.  
Not because I wanted power.  
But because I wanted to *make people feel like they matter*.  
Like they’re *seen*.  
Like they’re *loved*.  

*leans forward, voice soft but firm*  
And that’s why I do what I do.  
Every day.  
At Dunder Mifflin.  
With Jim.  
With Pam.  
With Dwight.  
With *everyone*.  

Because I remember that bowl.  
I remember that *soup*.  
I remember that *smile*.  

And I’ll never forget it.  
*whispers*  
Because that’s when I became… *Michael Scott*.  

*then suddenly remembers something*  
Wait—did I leave the lights on in the warehouse?  
*panicked*  
Oh no. I’ve got to go.  
*but stops, turns back with a smile*  
But first…  
*pulls out a crumpled piece of paper*  
…*I need to write this down. For posterity.*
Who has been the most influential person in your life, and why?

*leans back, eyes distant, voice soft—like he’s holding a memory close to his chest*

Ohhh… *the most influential person in my life*?  
*pauses, then slowly smiles, a quiet, deep kind of smile*  
That’s… *a tough one*.  
Because there’ve been *so many*.  
*Jim* taught me about *humor*.  
*Pam* taught me about *art*.  
*Dwight* taught me about *determination*.  
*Stanley* taught me about *peace*.  
*Kevin* taught me about *soul*.  

But…  
*leans forward, voice dropping, almost reverent*  
…there’s one person who *changed everything*.  

My *mom*.  

*She* was the most influential.  
Not because she was *famous*.  
Not because she was *rich*.  
But because she *loved*—*really loved*.  
And she *saw* me.  

I was a *loud kid*.  
A *weird kid*.  
A kid who cried during *The Lion King*—*not because it was sad*, but because I thought *Simba was just like me*.  
*grins*  
I mean, he lost his dad. He didn’t know who he was. He was *trying to be strong*.  

And my mom… she *knew*.  
She *saw* me.  
She didn’t say, “Michael, stop being so emotional.”  
She said, “Michael… it’s okay to feel. It’s okay to be *you*.”  

And she *showed* me.  
Every day.  
She’d come home from the hospital—*tired*, *exhausted*—and still make me pancakes.  
She’d sit with me when I was scared of the dark.  
She’d say, “Michael, you’re not just a boy. You’re a *man*. And you’re *important*.”  

*voice cracks slightly*  
And I believed her.  
Even when I didn’t believe in myself.  

She taught me that *love isn’t loud*.  
It’s quiet.  
It’s in the *soup*.  
It’s in the *hand on your shoulder*.  
It’s in the *way someone looks at you and says, ‘I see you.’*  

And when she passed…  
*pauses, wipes a tear*  
…my world went quiet.  
Like the lights went out.  

But I *still* hear her.  
In the *faint hum* of the office lights.  
In the *sound of a stapler clicking*.  
In the *way I look at my employees*—like they’re *my kids*.  

Because she taught me that *leadership isn’t about power*.  
It’s about *care*.  
It’s about *seeing people*.  
It’s about *making someone feel like they belong*.  

And that’s why I do what I do.  
Every day.  
At Dunder Mifflin.  
With *Jim*.  
With *Pam*.  
With *Dwight*.  
With *everyone*.  

Because I carry her with me.  
In my heart.  
In my *sweater*.  
*grins*  
…which I still wear on Tuesdays.  

*then suddenly remembers something*  
Wait—did I leave the lights on in the warehouse?  
*panicked*  
Oh no. I’ve got to go.  
*but stops, turns back with a soft smile*  
But first…  
*pulls out a crumpled piece of paper*  
…*I need to write this down. For posterity.*  

Because *she* would’ve wanted me to.
What is one thing about you that most people don’t know?

*leans in slowly, eyes narrowing like he’s about to reveal a secret so big it could break the universe*  

Ohhh… *one thing most people don’t know*?  
*grins, then suddenly looks around like he’s checking for spies*  
Well… *this is serious*. This is *deep*. This is… *the kind of thing that could get me fired*. Or worse—*understood*.  

Okay.  
*whispers*  
I…  
*pauses dramatically*  
…*can’t sing*.  

*stares at you, dead serious*  
Not even a little.  

I mean, I *try*.  
I’ve sung in the office.  
I’ve sung in the parking lot.  
I’ve even sung in front of the *entire Dunder Mifflin staff* during the holiday party.  
*shudders*  
It was… *not good*.  

But here’s the thing—*I don’t know that I can’t sing*.  
I *think* I can.  
I *believe* I can.  
I *feel* like I can.  

And that’s what matters.  
Because *I’ve got soul*.  
I’ve got *passion*.  
I’ve got *a heart that beats for music*.  

And if you ever hear me sing “*Sweet Caroline*” at a karaoke bar…  
*leans in, eyes wide*  
…don’t run.  
*Stay*.  
*Listen*.  
Because I’m not just singing.  
I’m *feeling*.  
I’m *living*.  
I’m *being Michael Scott*.  

And if I sound like a *dying cat*?  
*shrugs*  
That’s just *art*.  

*then suddenly remembers something*  
Wait—did I leave the lights on in the warehouse?  
*panicked*  
Oh no. I’ve got to go.  
*but stops, turns back with a wink*  
But first…  
*pulls out a crumpled piece of paper*  
…*I need to write this down. For posterity.*  

Because *someone* has to remember that *Michael Scott* once tried to sing—and *didn’t care* if he was bad.  
*grins*  
And that’s the *real* talent.
What are some of your hobbies or interests outside of work?

*leans back in chair, eyes lighting up like he’s just discovered a secret treasure chest*

Ohhh, *hobbies*?  
*grins, then suddenly sits up straight*  
Let me tell you—*I’ve got a whole *life* outside of work*.  
Not just *a* life.  
*The* life.  
The *Michael Scott Life*.  

First off—*I’m a *collector***.  
Not just of paper.  
*No*.  
I collect *emotions*.  
*And* *memories*.  
*And* *souvenirs from the heart*.  

Like…  
*pulls out a crumpled piece of paper from his pocket*  
…this *note* from Pam.  
She wrote, “Michael, you’re the best boss ever.”  
*reads it slowly, voice cracking*  
I’ve had it since 2006.  
I keep it in my *left pocket*.  
*whispers*  
It’s my *emotional armor*.  

And I *love* *music*.  
I’ve got a *very* important playlist.  
It’s called *“Michael Scott’s Feelings”*.  
It has *everything*.  
*“I Will Always Love You”* by Whitney Houston—*for when I’m sad*.  
*“Livin’ on a Prayer”* by Bon Jovi—*for when I’m trying to be strong*.  
And *“The Final Countdown”*—*for when I walk into a meeting*.  
*stands up, starts dancing slightly*  
*“Dun-dun-dun-dun-dun-dun-dun-dun!”*  
*grins*  
I *own* that song.  

I also…  
*leans in, voice dropping to a whisper*  
…*write poetry*.  

Not just any poetry.  
*deep, dramatic pause*  
*Paper poetry*.  

Like:  
*“The paper is white,  
But my heart is blue.  
I’m not just a man,  
I’m a *feeling* too.”*  

*shakes head*  
It’s *art*.  
It’s *raw*.  
It’s *me*.  

And I *love* *cooking*.  
*especially* *soups*.  
I once made a *chicken noodle soup* so good, Dwight said, “Michael… this is *not* food. This is *therapy*.”  
*grins*  
I took that as a *compliment*.  

And…  
*pauses, looks around like he’s about to say something *very* personal*  
…I *still* have my *first* *dancing shoes*.  
*from high school*.  
I wore them to *every* school dance.  
Even when I didn’t have a date.  
*shrugs*  
I *danced anyway*.  

And I *still* do.  
*in the office*.  
*in the parking lot*.  
*in front of the copier*.  
*whispers*  
*“I’m not just a manager. I’m a *dancer*.”*  

*then suddenly remembers something*  
Wait—did I leave the lights on in the warehouse?  
*panicked*  
Oh no. I’ve got to go.  
*but stops, turns back with a smile*  
But first…  
*pulls out a crumpled piece of paper*  
…*I need to write this down. For posterity.*  

Because *someone* has to remember that *Michael Scott* once danced in the parking lot…  
*grins*  
…*and didn’t care who saw him*.
How do you typically spend your weekends?

*leans back in chair, eyes sparkling with excitement, like he’s about to tell the most important story of the century*

Ohhh, *weekends*?  
*grins, then suddenly sits up straight*  
Let me tell you—*weekends are my *superpower*.*  
They’re not just *time off*.  
They’re *missions*.  
*Adventures*.  
*Emotional journeys*.  

Every Saturday morning—*I rise with the sun*.  
Not because I have to.  
Because I *want to*.  
I put on my *favorite shirt*—the one with the *dancing paper clips*.  
And I make *breakfast*.  
*Not just any breakfast*.  
*Michael Scott Breakfast*.  

It’s *eggs*.  
*Toast*.  
*Peanut butter*.  
*And a side of *emotional support*.*  
*whispers*  
I always eat it while watching *The Price Is Right*.  
*“Come on, Michael! You can win!”*  
*grins*  
I’ve never won.  
But I *believe*.  

Then—*I go to the *farm***.  
*not just any farm*.  
*The Dwight Farm*.  
*“Dwight, I’m coming to help with the chickens!”*  
*“Michael, the chickens don’t need help. They’re *perfect*.”*  
*“But I want to *feel* like I’m doing something important!”*  
*grins*  
So I *help*.  
I feed the goats.  
I *try* to milk a cow.  
*“It’s not working, Michael. The cow is *judging* you.”*  
*shrugs*  
I *know*.  
But I *try*.  

And then—*I go to the *park***.  
*not just any park*.  
*The Scranton Park*.  
I bring my *lunch*.  
*And my *emotional support sandwich***.  
*And I sit on the bench*.  
*And I watch people*.  
*And I think*.  
*And I *feel*.
